questions.text: A vagabond roaming in the forest eats some unknown fruits. After sometime he starts having symptoms of irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

Diagnostic features of Datura poisoning in the question

 

  • Datura has mainly neurotoxic (Irritability, restlessness) and anticholinergic features (Dry hot skin, unable to urinate and pass stool)
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for Datura

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.
  • Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.
  • Features of Datura poisoning (D's of Datura): Dry hot skin, Dilatation of pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium, Drowsiness, Death.
  • Datura causes constipation, not diarrhoea

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning:

 

  • Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug.
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice
  • Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning, not for anticholinergic toxicity caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside and not an antidote. The treatment for yellow oleander poisoning includes atropine and antiarrhythmics, not digoxin.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Physostigmine is not the antidote for yellow oleander poisoning, which primarily affects the heart rather than causing anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • There are two oleander plants: Nerium odorum and Cerbera Thevetia
  • Both are cardiac poisons
  • Both have digoxin like toxicity:
    • Heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse).
    • Similar to digitalis.
    •  Muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning.
  • Treatment of Both Oleander poisoning:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies for severe arrhythmias

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning is characterized by neurotoxic and anticholinergic symptoms, and the appropriate antidote is Physostigmine, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and reverse CNS toxicity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: The dead body of a 4-year-old child who was playing around the riverside and accidentally drowned in the river is recovered. There is frothing seen from his mouth and nose. Which of the below postmortem findings is not seen in a case of drowning? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to antemortem drowning.

 

This finding is unrelated to drowning and would suggest chronic arsenic poisoning rather than an acute drowning incident.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway
  • Water in the stomach and small intestine
  • Water in middle ear
  • Cerebral edema
  • Bloated and cyanosed face
  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.
  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs
  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils
  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours
  • Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist 
  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluminous and ballooned out lungs: Seen in drowning due to the inhalation of water.

 

Option C. Paltauf's hemorrhage in sub pleura: Hemorrhages found beneath the pleura, associated with drowning.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: Indicates a struggle and is a sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of drowning, typical findings include frothing from the mouth and nose, voluminous lungs, and cadaveric spasm with debris. High arsenic concentration in hair shafts is not associated with drowning.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old girl was brought to the OPD. Genital examination revealed the findings as given below: (AIIMS NOV 2018)

 

  • Labia majora - separated
  • Labia minora- flabby
  • Fourchette tear present
  • Roomy vagina seen with intact hymen

 

What is true about this girl from the options below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False virgin

 

The observed separated labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not a virgin. Despite having sexual intercourse, the hymen is intact so it is a case of false virgin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True virgin: Presence of labia majora, flabby labia minora, roomy vagina, and a fourchette tear suggest penetration (sexual intercourse). So, the girl is not true virgin.

 

Option C. Premenstrual change typically involve hormonal variations leading to breast tenderness, bloating, and mood swings rather than observable alterations in genital anatomy.

 

Option D. Molestation there would be sign of abrasions, bruising, edema, laceration or may have injuries to the vulva, hymen, vagina and the perineum. Since these signs are not present chances of molestation are slim

 

Educational  Objective:

 

Please note that the features will be same for a deflorate woman and a false virgin with the exception of presence of hymen in the latter.

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediately

 

Immediate dilated fundus examination is recommended for individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, as early detection of diabetic retinopathy is crucial for preventing vision loss. Screening at diagnosis is essential because diabetic retinopathy can be asymptomatic in its early stages, yet still pose a risk of significant damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Before his 50th birthday: While this is within five years of diagnosis, immediate examination is preferred for immediate intervention and management.

 

Option C. After his 50th birthday: Delaying the examination could lead to unnoticed progression of diabetic retinopathy and potentially irreversible damage.

 

Option D. When he complains of decrease in vision: Waiting for symptoms such as decreased vision can result in delayed diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy, at which point some damage may be irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral and upward gaze

 

Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear nerve palsy, not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

 

Signs of oculomotor nerve palsy

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ptosis Occurs due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

 

Option B. Mid-dilated pupil: Results from paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle, leading to unopposed dilation by the sympathetic innervation.

 

Option C. Loss of light reflex: Occurs because the parasympathetic fibers controlling pupillary constriction are affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Oculomotor nerve palsy typically causes an "down and out" gaze due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, not a "lateral and upward" gaze, which would instead suggest trochlear nerve involvement.

choices.text: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases
Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Transferrin receptor 1 iron responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Ferritin mRNA concentration iron responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the internal iron homeostasis in iron-deficiency anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis

 

In iron deficiency anemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis.

 

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases: This statement is incorrect. In iron deficiency, ferritin synthesis decreases as the body conserves iron, but the ferritin mRNA concentration does not increase.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis: This is incorrect because in iron deficiency, transferrin receptor 1 expression increases to maximize iron uptake.

 

Option D. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases: This is also incorrect. In iron deficiency, both ferritin mRNA levels and ferritin synthesis decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron-deficiency anemia, transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increase mRNA concentration and synthesis to enhance iron uptake, while ferritin levels decrease as the body attempts to conserve iron.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 1231-1234

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

 

  • Lot of blackening is easily visible around the firearm wound in the image.
  • Burning, blackening and tattooing are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds typically do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are generally larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds lack the features of burning, blackening, and tattooing. The wound edges are usually cleaner.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Similar to close shot exit wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not have burning, blackening, or tattooing and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: A patient has adult respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is the action of IL-8 in the pathogenesis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neutrophil activation

 

In the pathogenesis of Adult Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), Interleukin-8 (IL-8) plays a crucial role as a potent chemokine that specifically attracts and activates neutrophils.

 

Neutrophil activation is a critical step in the inflammatory cascade that exacerbates endothelial injury and subsequent lung damage in ARDS. Neutrophils, once activated, release proteases, reactive oxygen species, and other inflammatory mediators that contribute to the damage of the alveolar-capillary membrane, further aggravating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury: While endothelial injury is an important early event in ARDS, it is not directly caused by IL-8. Instead, endothelial injury triggers the release of cytokines, including IL-8, which then leads to neutrophil recruitment and activation.

 

Option C. Fibrin deposition: Fibrin deposition is a downstream event in ARDS and is a result of the damage caused by neutrophil activation and endothelial injury. IL-8 indirectly contributes to this through its role in neutrophil activation, but it is not directly responsible for fibrin deposition.

 

Option D. Macrophage activation: While macrophages are involved in the inflammatory response in ARDS, IL-8 primarily targets neutrophils, not macrophages. IL-8's main action is to attract and activate neutrophils rather than macrophages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-8 is a key mediator in ARDS that promotes neutrophil activation, which plays a major role in the amplification of inflammation and lung injury in the disease process.

questions.text:
Blood examination shows pancytopenia, which can be correct? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Megaloblastic anemia
  2. Hairy cell leukemia
  3. MDS with hypocellular BM
  4. APML
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Megaloblastic anemia (hypocellular phase), hairy cell leukemia, and MDS (hypocellular bone marrow) can show pancytopenia.

 

  1. Megaloblastic anemia: This type of anemia, often caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, can lead to pancytopenia, especially in its more severe or hypocellular phase. The bone marrow in megaloblastic anemia can show hypercellularity with ineffective hematopoiesis, but in some cases, it can present as hypocellular, contributing to pancytopenia.
  2. Hairy cell leukemia: This is a type of chronic B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. It is commonly associated with pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration by hairy cells and associated fibrosis, which suppresses normal hematopoiesis.
  3. MDS with hypocellular BM: Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of hematologic conditions characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis and dysplasia in one or more of the myeloid cell lines. In cases of MDS with a hypocellular bone marrow, pancytopenia can occur due to the reduced production of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is typically not associated with pancytopenia. APML usually presents with leukocytosis or normal white cell counts, along with thrombocytopenia and anemia. However, severe pancytopenia is not a characteristic feature, and therefore, APML is not typically associated with pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia –

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity e.g.

 

  1. Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3. Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (page 314)

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations e.g.

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fissured 

 

Image shows thin lines, which are not displaced. This is characteristic of fissured (linear) #

 

Fissured (linear) fractures present as thin, non-displaced lines and are the most common type of skull fracture, typically resulting from broad surface impacts, such as in road traffic accidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring Fracture: Caused by a fall from height, presenting as a fracture around the foramen magnum.

 

Option B. Depressed Fracture: Caused by heavy objects with a small surface area, takes the shape of the weapon.

 

Option D. Hinge Fracture: Divides the skull into anterior and posterior halves, often associated with motorcyclist injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Skull fractures 

 

  1. Linear fracture/ primary fracture/ fissured fracture                                                 
    • Fracture looks like a thin line 
    • Due to striking with a broad surface, e.g. ground 
    • Most common skull fracture, 
    • Usually seen in Road traffic accident
       

  2. Depressed fracture/ signature fracture 

    • Due to a heavy objects with small surface area . e.g. hammer 
    • Takes the shape of the weapon 

     

  3. Indented fracture / ping pong fracture / ponds #
    • Skull is depressed like a ping pong ball 
    • Seen in infants 
       
  4. Gutter fracture 
    • Long narrow depressed fracture 
    • Bullet passing adjacent to skull 
       
  5. Sutural fracture / diastatic fracture 
    • Sutures separate
    • Seen In <3 yrs of age 
       
  6. Ring fracture 
    • Cause – fall from height 
    • # around foramen magnum 
    • Associated # of vertebrae 
       
  7. Hinge fracture / motorcyclist fracture 
    • Skull divided into anterior and posterior halves 
       
  8. Spider web fracture / mosaic fracture / comminuted fracture 
    • Multiple fractures of skull

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

 

  • The clinical vignette suggests anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like latanoprost increase uveoscleral outflow and lower intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues act by stimulating prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases that increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Prostaglandin analogues should be used with caution in patients with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis.
  • Prostaglandin analogues are the least suited for use in this patient as they can worsen the anterior uveitis.
  • PG Analogues can also cause cystoids macular edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: These are generally safe in uveitis unless contraindicated for systemic reasons.

 

Option B. Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic can be used for quick reduction of IOP in acute settings but does not exacerbate uveitis.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Also safe for use in reducing IOP in uveitis, unless systemic contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.

questions.text: A patient had a pulmonary mass which shows IHC staining with TTF-1 as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma lung

 

Thyroid Transcription Factor-1 (TTF-1) is a nuclear protein that is a specific marker for adenocarcinoma of the lung and small cell carcinoma of the lung. However, it is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma.

 

TTF-1 positivity indicates that the tumor cells are likely of lung or thyroid origin, with adenocarcinoma being the most common type of lung cancer associated with this marker.

 

Additionally, other markers like Napsin A and surfactant protein A1 are also specific to adenocarcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell cancer lung: Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows markers like P63, P40, or keratin. It does not stain positive for TTF-1, differentiating it from adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Small cell carcinoma lung: While TTF-1 can be positive in small cell carcinoma, other specific markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and INSM-1 are more indicative. TTF-1's presence alone, along with the given context, makes adenocarcinoma the more likely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma lung: This is generally a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have specific immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1. Large cell carcinoma is generally a diagnosis of exclusion, as it lacks specific markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TTF-1 is a key immunohistochemical marker that strongly suggests adenocarcinoma of the lung, particularly when observed in a pulmonary mass.

questions.text: A child before playing consumed fruit from the garden. After some time, he developed a high fever, confusion, photophobia, and unable to urinate. What are the likely causative agent and the appropriate antidote used in this case? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

H/O consumption of a fruit, high fever, confusion, photophobia, unable to urinate are anticholinergic symptoms. Photophobia occurs due to mydriasis in anticholinergic poisoning.

 

Datura poisoning:

 

Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.

 

Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.

 

Features of Datura poisoning:

 

 D's of Datura

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death

 

Datura Flowers: Flowers are large tubular (trumpet-shaped) which may be white (alba) or purple (Niger)

 

Datura Fruit capsule: It is spherical with soft spines and contains 50 to 100 dark brown reniform (kidney-shaped) seeds which bear a superficial resemblance to chilly seeds

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning: Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug, physostigmine [Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity]

 

Below image shows Datura Flower and Datura Fruit

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. While Datura is the correct causative agent, Pralidoxime is not the correct antidote. Pralidoxime is used in the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not anticholinergic poisoning caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Pralidoxime: Incorrect. Yellow oleander poisoning presents primarily with symptoms of cardiac toxicity, such as arrhythmias and heart failure, not the anticholinergic symptoms described in the question. Additionally, Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Incorrect. Again, Yellow oleander would cause symptoms related to cardiac toxicity rather than the anticholinergic symptoms presented. Physostigmine is not the antidote for Yellow oleander poisoning.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • Types:
  1. Nerium odorum (White Oleander): Bears white, dark red or pink flowers
  2. Cerbera thevetia (Yellow Oleander): Bears yellow bell-shaped flowers, globular fruits

 

 

  • Symptoms: In both oleanders there will symptoms of heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse) and muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning. They are similar to digitalis causing death from cardiac failure.
  • Treatment:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine is useful in the management of ventricular tachyarrhythmias, premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), and bigeminy.
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies (digoxin-specific Fab fragments) are the treatment of choice for severe bradyarrhythmia’s with hypotension unresponsive to atropine and life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling and difficulty in swallowing food. Histopathological examination of the swelling shows increased nests of cells with amyloid deposition. Which of the following is the cell of origin of this mass?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parafollicular cells

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is the type of thyroid cancer associated with increased nests of cells and amyloid deposition. MTC arises from the parafollicular cells (also known as C cells) of the thyroid. These cells produce calcitonin, a hormone involved in calcium homeostasis. The presence of amyloid in MTC is due to the deposition of calcitonin, which can be detected as amyloid material in histopathological examinations. This type of thyroid cancer is distinct from other forms such as papillary, follicular, or anaplastic thyroid carcinomas, which originate from follicular cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial cells: Incorrect. Endothelial cells line blood vessels and are not associated with thyroid tumors that show amyloid deposition.

 

Option C. Follicular cells: Incorrect. Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid cancers, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hurthle cells: Incorrect. Hurthle cells are a variant of follicular cells and can be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, another type of thyroid cancer, but not in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, characterized by nests of cells and amyloid deposition, arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid.

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. He has a retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise.  There is no mucosal bleeding in the patient. Which of the following coagulation factor can be responsible for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor 8/9 deficiency

 

The presence of recurrent deep tissue bleeding (retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise) in a male is suggestive of a clotting factor deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency: Typically presents with mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time, not deep tissue bleeding as described.

 

Option C. Lupus anticoagulant: Usually associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to a paradoxical increase in thrombosis rather than bleeding.

 

Option D. Factor 9/12 deficiency: Factor XII deficiency does not cause significant bleeding and is usually discovered incidentally with prolonged aPTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia, caused by deficiencies in factors VIII or IX, presents with recurrent deep tissue bleeding and hemarthrosis, without significant mucosal bleeding. This differentiates it from other bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enlarged blind spots

 

The correct answer is Enlarged blind spots. The image shows a significant enlargement of the physiological blind spot, which is a hallmark of conditions such as papilledema. Papilledema is a condition characterized by optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling leads to an enlarged blind spot-on visual field testing, which is prominently seen in the images provided.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Altitudinal field defects: These defects present as a loss of vision above or below the horizontal line, resembling a band-like defect across the visual field. This type of defect is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy or branch retinal artery or vein occlusion.

 

 

Option C. Arcuate field defects: Arcuate defects appear as arc-shaped visual losses that extend from the blind spot and follow the nerve fiber layer pattern. This type of defect is typically seen in glaucoma and other optic neuropathies.

 

 

Option D. Roennes nasal step: This defect is characterized by a step-like pattern near the nasal visual field, commonly seen in glaucoma. It occurs due to the asymmetry between the superior and inferior nerve fiber bundles

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enlarged blind spots on visual field testing are indicative of conditions like papilledema, where optic disc swelling leads to an increased physiological blind spot

questions.text: What is the causative agent for Hooch tragedy? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Methanol

 

Hooch tragedy is due to the consumption of adulterated liquor containing methanol. Methanol is a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health issues including blindness, metabolic acidosis, and death when ingested.

 

Hooch

 

  • Definition: It is ethyl alcohol illegally adulterated with other harmful substances
  • Methanol as adulterant: A common harmful adulterant in hooch is methanol
  • Sources of methanol in Ethanol: There are two ways by which methanol gets added in the ethanol:
    • Added deliberately to ethanol due to its low price or
    • Produced during ethanol production (fermentation): Methanol can get naturally produced along with ethanol during the production of ethanol by fermentation. Usually it gets removed by distillation, but in local and illegal production, the distillation is of poor quality.
  • Hooch tragedy in India: In India, local alcohol is made illegally from cane sugar, is sold very cheap for a plastic pouch or glass. In Bihar and some other states, it has resulted in deaths of multiple people at different times

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning usually occurs due to ingestion of substances like rodenticides or fireworks and is not associated with hooch tragedies.

 

Option B. Mercury: Mercury poisoning occurs from exposure to mercury or its compounds and is not linked to hooch tragedies.

 

Option C. Ethanol: Ethanol is the intended product of alcoholic beverages. It is not the cause of hooch tragedies unless it is adulterated with toxic substances like methanol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hooch tragedies occur due to the consumption of illicitly brewed liquor contaminated with methanol, a toxic form of alcohol that can cause severe health effects including death.

questions.text:
Arrange symptoms as in their order of appearance as seen in iron toxicity:(INICET MAY 2021)

  1. Pyloric stricture
  2. Asymptomatic phase
  3. Gastrointestinal bleeding
  4. Liver failure and hypoglycemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3 → 2 → 4 → 1

 

Iron toxicity progresses through several stages, each with distinct symptoms that appear in a specific order. The stages are:

 

 

Treatment of Iron toxicity – Deferoxamine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron toxicity progresses through distinct stages, starting with gastrointestinal irritation and bleeding, followed by an asymptomatic phase, then liver failure and hypoglycemia, and finally, bowel obstruction leading to pyloric stricture.

choices.text: Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop
Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface

questions.text: What is the function of Acetone Free Methanol in Leishman stain? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop

Acetone-free methanol serves as a fixing agent in the Leishman stain process. Its primary function is to cause metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop, which preserves cellular architecture. This fixation occurs through protein denaturation and halts all biological processes, maintaining the cellular structure for microscopic examination. Therefore, the correct choice would be: "Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop."

 

The procedure of Leishman stain:

  • Freshly prepare and rapidly air-dry blood film.
  • Cover the film with Leishman's Stain (S018S) and allow it to act for 1 minute. Methanol in the stain fixes the preparation.
  • Add double the volume of distilled water to the slide and mix.
  • Allow the diluted stain to act for 10-12 minutes.
  • Wash the film with distilled water or phosphate buffer of pH 7.0, drain and dry in air and examine

 

Other Options:

Option B. Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface: This is incorrect because methanol doesn't prevent adhesion; rather, it preserves cellular structure through protein denaturation.

 

Option C. Colors the red cells: This is not the role of acetone-free methanol. The actual coloring of the cells is performed by the dye components in the Leishman stain (methylene blue and eosin).

 

Option D. Fixes cells to slide: While methanol is a fixative, its primary mechanism is stopping metabolic activity, not adhering cells to the slide. As previously noted, adhesion to the slide surface is the function of substances like albumin.
 

Educational Objective:


Acetone-free methanol in the Leishman stain primarily functions by causing metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop through protein denaturation, which preserves cellular architecture and enables proper staining and microscopic examination.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

choices.text: Child Welfare Committee

questions.text: A young girl refuses to go to Mathematics class everyday citing abnormal excuses. It was discovered by the principal that the mathematics teacher was touching her genitalia inappropriately. The duty of the principal is to report this to?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Police

 

Explanation:

 

Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, the principal should refer to Section 19 which states that “Any person who has apprehension that an offence under this Act is likely to be committed or has knowledge that such an offence has been committed shall provide such information to the Special Juvenile Police Unit or the local police.”

 

Other options

 

Option A) Magistrate, Option C) child welfare committee, Option D) Parents: According to POCSO Act, Article 19, the immediate duty is to inform the police when there is knowledge or apprehension of a child being sexually abused. Others can be informed later.

 

Educational Objective

 

POCSO Act Provisions

 

  • Section 19 of the Act makes it mandatory for any person including the child to approach the police in case of an apprehension that an offence under the Act is likely to be committed or "has the knowledge" that such an act has been committed.

 

 The POCSO act defines a child as any person below eighteen years of age. It defines various forms of sexual offenses which include:

 

  • ﻿﻿﻿Sexual harassment - Threatening
  • ﻿﻿﻿Sexual assault - Any act with sexual intent that involves physical contact without penetration.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated sexual assault - Similar to sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  • ﻿﻿﻿Penetrative sexual assault - An act with sexual intent that involves physical penetration of the penis or any object into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Aggravated penetrative sexual assault - Similar to penetrative sexual assault along with the criteria explained under the term aggravated
  • ﻿﻿﻿Pornography

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

Thymoma is the most likely diagnosis for the clinical presentation of a mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a rare syndrome characterized by a selective failure of erythroid element production in the bone marrow but normal granulopoiesis and megakaryocytopoiesis.

 

The patients have normocytic normochromic anemia, with normal granulocyte and platelet counts. Reticulocytes are significantly reduced or absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma:

 

Association: While lymphomas can present as mediastinal masses and may cause cytopenias, they are not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic Carcinoma:

 

Association: Bronchogenic carcinoma typically presents with respiratory symptoms and does not have a known association with PRCA.

 

Option D. Germ cell tumor:

 

Association: Germ cell tumors can present as mediastinal masses but are not specifically linked to PRCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a patient with pure red cell aplasia. PRCA is characterized by a selective deficiency of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia with normal granulocyte and platelet counts, and is often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: Identify the plant which produces a toxin of abuse potential? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erythroxylum coca

 

The plant in the picture is Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by red berries.

 

Cocaine, a substance with significant abuse potential, is derived from this plant.

 

Other Options

 

Option B Datura: It can be identified by:

 

  • Green color fruit with sharp spines
  • Large trumpet shaped flowers

 

Datura flower and fruit images shown below:

 

 

Option C Digitalis Purpura: It can be identified by: 

 

  • Leaves are spirally arranged and covered with gray-white hairs, imparting a woolly texture.
  • Flowers are arranged in an elongated cluster, and each flower is tubular and pendent.

 

Digitalis purpura Flower and Plant images shown below:

 

 

Option D Cannabis: It can be identified by: 

 

  • Leaves have a digitate shape, with serrated edges. Leaflets are arranged opposite each other along the stem and are usually symmetrically aligned.

 

Cannabis leaves images shown below:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine is obtained from Erythroxylum coca, which can be identified by following features:

 

  • Leaves: Characteristic of the leaf is an areolated portion bounded by two longitudinal curved lines, one line on each side of the midrib.
  • Flowers are small, and disposed in little clusters on short stalks.
  • Red Berries: The flowers mature into red berries.

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

questions.text:
Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis?

 

  1. Triangular obturator foramen

  2. U-shaped pubic angle

  3. Everted ischial tuberosity

  4. Large greater sciatic notch

  5. Large acetabulum

  6. Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only 5   

 

Large acetabulum: The acetabulum in males is generally larger to support a greater range of motion and the weight of a more muscular body.

 

Other Features:

 

1. Triangular obturator foramen: Typically seen in males.

 

2. U-shaped pubic angle: This is more characteristic of the female pelvis, which has a wider pubic angle to facilitate childbirth.

 

3. Everted ischial tuberosity: This is more common in females.

 

4. Large greater sciatic notch: More pronounced in females.

 

6. Deep preauricular sulcus: More commonly seen in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between male and female pelvis

questions.text: All blood products are separated by Centrifugation except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum albumin

 

Most blood components are separated using centrifugation, which involves different speeds:

 

  1. Low-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates Packed RBCs from platelet-rich plasma (PRP).
  2. High-speed centrifugation:
    • Separates platelets from plasma.
    • Plasma is further processed into Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP).
  3. Cryoprecipitate Preparation:
    • FFP is thawed at 1-6°C, allowing cryoprecipitate to form, which contains Factor VIII, fibrinogen, vWF, and Factor XIII.

 

Thus, platelets, RBCs and cryoprecipitate are all separated using centrifugation.

 

Serum albumin, however, is obtained through a process called fractionation, not centrifugation. This involves:

 

  • Cold ethanol precipitation (Cohn’s method)
  • Ultrafiltration and chromatography techniques

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centrifugation is used to separate RBCs, platelets, and plasma-derived components like cryoprecipitate. Serum albumin, however, is obtained through fractionation, making it the correct answer.

choices.text: Transfusion related circulatory overload

questions.text: A CKD patient had to undergo dialysis and his Hb was 5.2gm/dL. So two blood transfusions were to be given. The first bag was completed in 2 hours. The second was started and in the midway, he developed shortness of breath and hypertension. Vitals Were BP - 180/120 mmHg and pulse rate - 110 min. What is the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transfusion related circulatory overload

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).

 

Transfusion associated circulatory overload includes any four of the following occurring within 6 h of a blood transfusion - acute respiratory distress, tachycardia, increased blood pressure (BP), acute or worsening pulmonary edema and evidence of a positive fluid balance.

 

TACO may occur due to rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products.

 

Prevented is by slow transfusion at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allergic: Allergic reactions to blood transfusions usually present with urticaria (hives), pruritus (itching), and sometimes anaphylaxis, but do not typically cause the significant hypertension and tachycardia seen in this case.

 

Option C. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): TRALI is characterized by acute onset of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, leading to respiratory distress and hypoxemia during or within 6 hours of transfusion. However, TRALI typically presents with hypotension or normal blood pressure, not the significant hypertension seen here.

 

Option D. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction: This reaction typically presents with fever, chills, and rigors, but does not cause the hemodynamic instability (hypertension and tachycardia) seen in TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transfusion-related circulatory overload (TACO) is a potential complication of blood transfusion, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions like CKD. It presents with respiratory distress, hypertension, and tachycardia and can be prevented by careful monitoring and slow transfusion.

questions.text: Identify the following image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Blister due to antemortem burns

 

The antemortem blister presents itself as an elevated dome, containing serous fluid enriched with proteins and chlorides. The surrounding base exhibits reddening and swollen papillae. In the case of antemortem burns, the adjacent skin displays heightened enzyme activity, particularly for sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers. This reaction is accompanied by increased levels of ATP, esterase’s, aminopeptidases, acid, and alkaline phosphatase. These vital reactions indicate notable cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, which are distinctive features of antemortem burns.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blister due to barbiturate poisoning: Barbiturate poisoning typically causes CNS depression, respiratory issues, and cardiovascular problems, not specific blister formation like burns.

 

Option C. Edema due to chemical burn: Chemical burns might cause edema, but the specific blister shown in the image is more characteristic of thermal burns.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris: Pemphigus vulgaris presents with flaccid blisters and erosions rather than the tense blister shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antemortem burn blisters are characterized by elevated domes filled with serous fluid, reddened surrounding base, and high enzyme activity, indicating significant cellular and tissue reactions distinct from other types of blisters or burns.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen’s chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The largest letter on a Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc at any standard testing distance is essential for interpreting visual acuity results correctly. This standardization is fundamental in diagnosing and measuring visual acuity across different settings and distances

choices.text: Ewing's sarcoma

questions.text: All are small round blue cell tumors except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemangioblastoma

 

Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.

 

Many childhood tumors have been collectively referred to as small round blue cell tumors due to their primitive histologic appearance.

 

The differential diagnosis of such tumors includes neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, lymphoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, Ewing sarcoma/primitive neuroectodermal tumor, medulloblastoma and retinoblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ewing's sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma is a classic example of a small round blue cell tumor. It is a highly malignant tumor that primarily affects bone and soft tissues, particularly in children and young adults.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a small round blue cell tumor of the eye, commonly seen in children. It is characterized by the presence of small, undifferentiated cells with hyperchromatic nuclei.

 

Option D. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is another example of a small round blue cell tumor. It arises from neural crest cells and is most commonly found in the adrenal glands or along the sympathetic chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemangioblastoma is not classified as a small round blue cell tumor, unlike Ewing's sarcoma, retinoblastoma, and neuroblastoma.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotrans pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 882

questions.text: A man wears female heels and a female dress to get sexual arousal. He is not interested in males. What is the diagnosis ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic Fetishism

 

Transvestic Fetishism is a condition where an individual wears clothing of the opposite sex primarily to achieve sexual arousal. The key aspect of this disorder is the act of cross-dressing for the purpose of sexual gratification, not because of a desire to be of the opposite gender or any issues with gender identity. The patient described is not interested in males and is engaging in cross-dressing purely for sexual arousal, fitting the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender Dysphoria involves a conflict between an individual’s biological sex and their gender identity, such as a biologically male person identifying as female or vice versa. There is no indication in this case of any gender identity issues; the patient cross-dresses purely for sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Homosexuality: Homosexuality refers to a sexual orientation characterized by attraction to individuals of the same sex. The scenario explicitly states that the man is not interested in males, ruling out homosexuality as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of gaining sexual pleasure from watching others when they are naked or engaged in sexual activity, usually without their knowledge or consent. There is no element of voyeuristic behavior described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic Fetishism is characterized by cross-dressing for sexual arousal without any associated desire to change one’s gender or sexual orientation.

questions.text: Isotype switching is seen in? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activated B cells  

 

Isotype switching is seen in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching: Conversion of one antibody class (isotype) to another resulting from the genetic rearrangement of heavy-chain constant-region genes in activated B cells.

 

Isotype switching is dependent on the presence of both antigens and cytokines secreted by T-cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Helper T cells: While Helper T cells (especially Th2 cells) provide the necessary cytokines that drive isotype switching in B cells, they themselves do not undergo isotype switching.

 

Option C. Cytotoxic T cells: Cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells) are involved in killing infected or cancerous cells and do not produce antibodies or undergo isotype switching.

 

Option D. Naive B cells: Naive B cells, which have not yet encountered their specific antigen, initially produce IgM and IgD. They do not undergo isotype switching until after activation by an antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotype switching is a process that occurs in activated B cells, allowing them to produce different classes of antibodies to effectively combat various types of pathogens.

choices.text: Environmental enteropathy
Celiac disease
Whipple's disease

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

 

The clinical presentation and histopathological findings point to celiac disease.

 

Celiac disease is sometimes referred to as celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. In genetically predisposed individuals, it is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the consumption of gluten-containing cereals such as Barley, Rye, Oat & Wheat (BROW)

 

Almost all celiac disease patients have the class II HLADQ2 or HLA-DQ8 allele.

 

Histopathology: Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis), crypt hyperplasia, and villous atrophy characterize the histopathology.

 

 

  • Prior to biopsy, noninvasive serologic tests are usually performed. The presence of IgA antibodies to tissue transglutaminase or IgA or IgG antibodies to deamidated gliadin is the most sensitive test. Anti-endomysial antibodies are more specific than other antibodies but less sensitive.
  • Clinical features: -
    • Malabsorption syndrome with chronic refractory anemia, chronic diarrhea, bloating, abdominal pain, and marked weight loss. A characteristic itchy, blistering skin lesion, dermatitis herpetiformis, can be present in as many as 10% of patients, and the incidence of lymphocytic gastritis and lymphocytic colitis is also increased.
    • Enteropathy associated T cell lymphoma
    • Small intestinal adenocarcinoma

 

Treatment – Gluten free diet results in symptomatic improvement for most patients, but a gluten-free diet may also reduce the risk of long-term complications including anemia, female infertility, osteoporosis, and cancer.

 

DAPSONE for dermatitis herpetiformis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Environmental enteropathy: Environmental enteropathy / tropical sprue is seen in tropical areas with poor sanitation. It is believed to be caused by one or more infectious agents that respond to antibiotics. Mucosa shows variable villous atrophy. Folic acid and B12 deficiency is common.

 

Option C. Whipple's disease: Whipple's disease is a multisystemic disease caused by T. whipplei. Small intestinal biopsy shows PAS-positive macrophages (see image below).

 

 

Option D. Chronic pancreatitis: Causes malabsorption due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. Not associated with the specific histopathological features seen in celiac disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.”

 

  • It first affects the involuntary muscles first starting with the myocardium
  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis in voluntary muscles
  • Order of appearance of Rigor mortis in different organs:

questions.text: Which of the following is an intranuclear immuno-histochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INSM

 

Intranuclear immunohistochemistry markers are specifically located within the nucleus of the cell, unlike cytoplasmic or membranous markers.

 

INSM (Insulinoma Associated Protein 1) is a novel intranuclear marker used for the detection of neuroendocrine tumors. It is particularly useful in diagnosing various types of neuroendocrine tumors, including small cell carcinoma of the lung, medullary thyroid cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma, and paraganglioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromogranin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option B. NCAM: Incorrect because it is a membranous marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option C. Synaptophysin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

INSM is an intranuclear marker for neuroendocrine tumors, distinguishing it from other cytoplasmic or membranous markers such as Chromogranin, NCAM, and Synaptophysin.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Correct sequence of events during inflammation:

 

  1. Rolling
  2. Cytokine mediated integrin activation
  3. Adhesion
  4. Migration

 

CELLULAR CHANGES DURING INFLAMMATION

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of intravascular cellular events during inflammation involves rolling, cytokine-mediated integrin activation, adhesion, and migration.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease 10th edition pg. 78-79

questions.text: A patient underwent LASIK for myopia and now is undergoing cataract surgery. What is the formula used for lens power calculation in this patient?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Haigis-L  

 

  • The Haigis-L regression formula is used for lens power calculation in patients undergoing cataract surgery with a past history of LASIK for myopia.
  • Corneal refractive surgery significantly affects the IOL power required, making standard IOL calculations unsuitable.
  • Several methods of calculating corneal refractive power are used, such as the double-K method, Masket and modified Masket, and Haigis-L formulas.
  • The Haigis-L regression formula uses statistical data to facilitate calculation on post-refractive surgery eyes using only standard inputs.
  • It may be prudent to utilize more than one method of IOL calculation.

 

NEWER IOL POWER CALCULATION FORMULAE FOR POST REFRACTIVE SURGERY PATIENTS ARE –

 

  • Wang-Koch-Maloney
  • Shammas
  • Haigis-L
  • Galilei
  • Potvin-Hill Pentacam
  • Barrett True K No History      

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK 1 and Option B. SRK 2: These are older formulas that do not account for post-refractive surgery changes in corneal curvature and are less accurate in such cases.

 

Option C. Hoffer Q: While useful for eyes with shorter axial lengths, this formula also does not specifically adjust for the changes induced by corneal refractive surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who have had previous corneal refractive surgery like LASIK, specialized IOL calculation formulas such as Haigis-L should be used to ensure accurate lens power calculation for cataract surgery. This formula specifically addresses the altered corneal parameters to provide a more precise refractive outcome.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

 

Ankyloblepharon is a condition where the upper and lower eyelids become attached to each other. This can happen as a congenital anomaly or due to adhesions that form during the healing process of traumatic wounds, ulcers, or chemical burns affecting the eyelid margins. Treatment involves removing the adhesions between the eyelid margins. In cases where adhesions extend to the angles, epithelial grafts should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Symblepharon is the adhesion between the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva in which the eyelids become adherent to the eyeball.

 

The image given below shows symblepharon.

 

 

Option C: Congenital blepharophimosis is a condition in which the extent of the palpebral fissure is decreased. It can be congenital or acquired and is due to a vertical skin fold at the lateral canthus. No treatment is required. In some cases, canthoplasty is done.

 

 

Option D: Congenital ptosis is a condition present since birth and is characterized by drooping of one or both upper eyelids due to developmental defects or weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle. The affected individuals may also have lid lag on downward gaze. The most common treatment for congenital ptosis is surgical correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloblepharon involves the fusion of the eyelid margins, which can be congenital or acquired, and requires surgical intervention to correct the adhesion and restore normal eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and was brought to emergency with stable vitals. Which wound is not expected:(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chop wound

 

In the context of a road traffic accident, different types of wounds can be expected depending on the nature of the injury.

 

Chop Wound typically caused by a heavy, sharp tool like an axe or a machete. These are not typically seen in road traffic accidents unless there is a very specific scenario involving such an implement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple Bruises: These are common in road traffic accidents due to blunt force trauma where the body strikes objects like the steering wheel, dashboard, or gets jostled against seat belts.

 

Option C. Graze Abrasion: Often occurs when the skin slides across a rough surface, such as in motorcycle accidents when the rider is dragged along the pavement.

 

Option D. Laceration: These are irregular tears in the skin commonly caused by blunt trauma, which is typical in road traffic accidents when sharp or rough metal edges and glass are involved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chop wounds are unusual in road traffic accidents .

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of unexplained weight loss, hematuria, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging studies reveal a large renal mass. A renal biopsy has the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromophobe carcinoma

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings are consistent with chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Chromophobe RCC is characterized histologically by large polygonal cells with distinct cell borders, perinuclear halos, and a "plant-like" or "resinoid" nuclear appearance.

 

The biopsy image shows these classic features, which differentiate chromophobe RCC from other renal cancer variants.

 

While clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of RCC, the histological findings of clear cytoplasm with perinuclear clearing are more characteristic of chromophobe carcinoma. This variant is less aggressive compared to clear cell RCC and is often diagnosed with specific features on histopathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clear cell carcinoma: This is the most common type of RCC, characterized by cells with clear cytoplasm due to the presence of glycogen and lipid, which are dissolved during processing. The biopsy image does not show these clear cells, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary RCC is characterized by the presence of papillary structures and foamy macrophages. The biopsy image lacks these papillary features, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Bellini duct carcinoma: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this rare and aggressive form of RCC shows infiltrative growth patterns with prominent desmoplastic reaction. The biopsy does not match these characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromophobe RCC is identified by cells with distinct borders, a plant-like or resinoid nucleus, and a perinuclear halo, distinguishing it from other RCC types.

questions.text: A patient who receives recurrent transfusions for thalassemia develops fever and chills during this time. There is no evidence of hemolysis. Which of the following measures can decrease the rate of transfusion reactions? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leuko-reduced RBCs

 

The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leuko-reduced RBCs

 

Fever (elevation of temperature by 1º C or 2º F) , chills, or rigors resulting from cytokines released by leukocyte in transfused red cell or platelet components is called as non-hemolytic febrile transfusion reaction. It is a diagnosis of exclusion, as hemolytic and septic reactions can present similarly.

 

Prevention –

 

  1. Pre-storage leukoreduction
  2. Acetaminophen if persistent fever
  3. Routine pretreatment with acetaminophen
  4. Use of platelet additive solution
  5. Plasma reduced or washed products if severe reactions
  6. Restrictive transfusion approach in high-risk patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: Antibiotics are not used to prevent transfusion reactions. They are used to treat bacterial infections and would not be effective in preventing FNHTR, which is not caused by bacterial contamination.

 

Option C. Irradiation: Irradiation of blood products is used to prevent transfusion-associated graft-versus-host disease (TA-GvHD), a different type of transfusion reaction, but it does not prevent FNHTR.

 

Option D. Washed RBCs: Washing RBCs removes plasma proteins and is used to prevent allergic reactions in patients with a history of severe allergic transfusion reactions, but it is not specifically aimed at preventing FNHTR. However, washed products can be used if the FNHTR is severe or recurrent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leuko-reduced RBCs are the preferred method to reduce the risk of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTR), especially in patients requiring frequent transfusions like those with thalassemia.

 

  • FNHTRs are commonly due to cytokines released from donor leukocytes or recipient antibodies against donor leukocytes.
  • Leukoreduction removes most white blood cells from the blood product, thereby:
    • Reducing cytokine accumulation
    • Lowering risk of FNHTRs
    • Also helps prevent HLA alloimmunization and CMV transmission

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Only Myasthenia gravis, among the conditions mentioned above, would show dramatic improvement after administration of an injection (Anti-ChE medication).

 

In myasthenia gravis, there is unilateral myogenic ptosis where, after a short rest, the symptoms recover rapidly.

 

A quick test in the office can be to ask the patient to look up and hold that position, and then observe if there is fatiguability of the levator muscle such that the upper eyelids start to drift downwards while the patient is looking up. The definitive diagnosis is made through various clinical, pharmacological and serologic tests.

 

Diagnostic Tests

 

1. Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test:

 

Edrophonium chloride inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby prolonging the presence of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This results in enhanced muscle strength. This test is only useful in patients with objective, measurable findings on physical exam, like ptosis or a tropia. In ptosis, a positive test is the elevation of eyelids in 2-5 minutes post administration of Tensilon. A negative response is no improvement within 3 minutes.

 

2. Ice Test:

 

This is also a simple diagnostic test that can be done in the clinic. It is highly sensitive and specific for MG. The ice test is useful for ptosis. An ice pack is applied to the affected upper eyelid for 2-5 minutes. A positive test is the improvement of ptosis by > 2mm or more. This transient improvement in ptosis is due to the cold decreasing the acetylcholinesterase break-down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th nerve palsy: This condition primarily causes abduction deficit (inability to move the eye laterally), which would not explain the ptosis nor improve with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option C. 3rd nerve palsy: Though it can cause ptosis and eye movement abnormalities, symptoms are due to mechanical dysfunctions or nerve damage and do not improve quickly with Anti-ChE medications.
