Option D. Horner syndrome: Characterized by ptosis, miosis (pupil constriction), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating), but does not involve hypotropia or improve dramatically with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane.
  • The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.
  • Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features.
  • A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Note:

 

The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fiber Electromyography

 

The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with painful oral mucosal lesions and blisters on her skin. A biopsy is performed, and direct immunofluorescence microscopy is used to examine the skin specimen. Based on this finding, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by painful mucosal lesions and skin blisters.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) image shows a characteristic "fishnet" or "chicken-wire" pattern due to IgG antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3, which are components of the desmosomes that connect epidermal cells.

 

The disruption of these desmosomes leads to acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation, as seen in pemphigus vulgaris. The presence of painful oral lesions further supports this diagnosis, as they are commonly seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid: This condition also presents with blisters but typically in older patients without mucosal involvement. DIF shows a linear pattern of IgG and C3 at the basement membrane zone, not the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is characterized by intensely pruritic vesicles and papules, typically on extensor surfaces. DIF shows granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, which is different from the fishnet pattern seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Lupus vulgaris: This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting with slow-growing reddish-brown nodules, not blisters. It does not show a fishnet pattern on DIF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris presents with painful oral lesions and skin blisters, and its hallmark DIF finding is the fishnet pattern due to antibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 50,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myoblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

 

The clinical picture of fatigue, splenomegaly, and peripheral blood smear findings suggest chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are used to detect the BCR-ABL gene, which is specific for CML.

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder that most commonly affects people in their fifth to sixth decade of life. A reciprocal (9;22) (g34;g11) translocation results in the creation of the chimeric BC-ABL gene (Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene differentiates ML from other myeloproliferative disorders and can be detected using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) .

 

Clinical characteristics:

 

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.

 

Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

 

Peripheral blood:

 

  • Severe leukocytosis with a leukocyte count that frequently exceeds 100,000 cells/mm, primarily composed of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Moderate normocytic normochromic anemia - Rising basophilia indicates impending blastic transformation.
  • The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • Blastic phase or blast crisis in CML satisfies the definition of acute leukemia by having more than 20% blood or marrow blasts.
  • Anemia of moderate severity - A rising basophilia is indicative of impending blastic transformation. - The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • A blast phase or blast crisis in CML meets the definition of acute leukemia by having blood or marrow blasts of more than 20%.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunophenotyping: Used for the diagnosis of various hematologic malignancies, particularly lymphoid neoplasms. It is less specific for CML.

 

Option  B. LAP score (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase): The LAP score is typically low in CML, but this test is less specific and has largely been replaced by molecular diagnostic techniques like FISH and PCR.

 

Option D. Flow cytometry: Useful for identifying and classifying hematologic malignancies based on cell surface markers but is not the most specific test for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are the most sensitive investigations for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the hallmark of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). These tests are crucial for accurate diagnosis and monitoring of CML.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was taken by her neighbour to the emergency department after an incident involving her husband. She reported that during a domestic altercation, her husband swung an axe at her left arm. Upon examination, a significant injury was observed on her upper left arm. The wound appeared deep, with jagged and irregular edges. The surrounding area showed signs of bruising. Based on the clinical scenario, what type of wound is likely to be present on the patient's upper left arm? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chop wound 

 

A heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, e.g. axe produces chop wounds. Chop wounds have features of both sharp and blunt force injuries. They are characterized by deep, jagged, and irregular edges with surrounding bruising.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incised wound:

 

  • Produced by lighter weapons like knife, blades etc.
  • Margins are not contused and abraded. 
  • Destruction of underlying tissues is less as compared to cop wound.

 

Option C. Lacerated wound:

 

  • Lacerations can result from accidents, falls, or impact with blunt objects.
  • Lacerated wounds are not clean cut, whereas incised and chop wounds are clean cut.

 

Option D. Abrasion:  In abrasions only the superficial skin is damaged. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cut laceration / chop wounds: 

 

  • Produced by a heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, E.g. axe, chopper
    • It has features of both blunt force (bruised and abraded margins, irregular margins) and sharp force (clean margins)
    • A deep and wide cut over the body tissues.
    • Marked destruction of underlying tissues
    • Below image shows chop wound by axe:

questions.text: Marshall’s triad of abrasion, bruise & punctate laceration is seen in which phase of bomb blast injury? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary

 

Marshall's triad is the most characteristic feature of secondary blast injury. It consists of multiple small abrasions, contusions, and punctate lacerations all over the body caused by fragments of bombs or flying debris. These injuries occur due to fragments and pieces being propelled by the blast. Secondary blast injuries account for most fatalities in bomb blast incidents.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Primary: Incorrect. Primary blast injury is caused by high-pressure waves affecting hollow organs. In air blast, it primarily affects the tympanic membrane, followed by lungs and GIT. In underwater blast, GIT is the main target.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Incorrect. Tertiary blast injury occurs when the victim is thrown away by blast wind (not wave). It's characterized by blunt trauma from impact with solid objects.

 

Option D. Quaternary: Incorrect. Quaternary blast injury, also called miscellaneous blast injury, includes all injuries not covered in the first three phases such as flash burns, respiratory injuries from gases, and psychiatric issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Marshall's triad (multiple small abrasions, contusions, and punctate lacerations) is characteristic of secondary blast injury caused by flying debris and bomb fragments.

 

Bomb Blast Injuries

questions.text: An infant (given below in the image) presents to ophthalmology OPD with lacrimation and photophobia. What is the diagnosis. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital Glaucoma

 

Congenital Glaucoma is a rare condition that can occur in babies and young children. It's caused by an abnormal development of the eye's drainage system, leading to increased intraocular pressure, which can damage the optic nerve. Symptoms can include photophobia, excessive tearing (lacrimation), and cloudy, enlarged corneas. Given the symptoms  described, congenital glaucoma is a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS): This is a group of metabolic disorders caused by the absence or malfunctioning of lysosomal enzymes needed to break down molecules called glycosaminoglycans. While MPS can affect the eyes, leading to problems like corneal clouding and glaucoma, the key symptoms often include developmental delay, skeletal and joint abnormalities, and coarse facial features. Eye-related symptoms are typically not the first presenting symptoms in MPS.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This refers to a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth. Congenital cataracts can cause a variety of symptoms including a noticeable white, grey, or yellow spot in the pupil, nystagmus (uncontrolled eye movements), and yes, potentially photophobia. However, lacrimation (excessive tearing) is not a typical symptom of cataracts.

 

Option D. Ophthalmia Neonatorum: This condition is a form of conjunctivitis that occurs in newborns. Typically, it's caused by bacteria acquired during passage through the birth canal from an infected mother. The primary symptoms include redness of the eyes, swelling of the eyelids, and discharge, which may be watery or pus-like. Photophobia can be a symptom, but it's not as common as in some other conditions like congenital glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Glaucoma should be suspected in infants presenting with photophobia, excessive tearing, and cloudy, enlarged corneas, as it is due to the abnormal development of the eye's drainage system leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Removal of the foreign body

 

The image shows an eye with a metallic foreign body causing a penetrating injury. In such cases, immediate removal of the foreign body is not recommended as an initial step because doing so may exacerbate the injury or lead to complications such as infection or further mechanical damage to the eye structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Proper Initial Steps Include:
 

Option B. Check for visual acuity: This helps assess the extent of damage to the eye's visual function and provides a baseline for future comparisons.

 

Option C. Give antibiotics: Prophylactic treatment to prevent infection, especially considering the risk introduced by the foreign object.

 

Option D. Do primary survey: Ensures that the patient's overall health and other potential life-threatening conditions are addressed (part of the ABCDE approach - Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure).

 

Further Management:

 

CT scan: To precisely locate the foreign body and any possible penetration into the orbital or cranial cavities, helping plan for surgical intervention.

 

Avoid MRI: Due to the risk of movement of the metallic object, which can cause more damage.

 

Surgical exploration and repair in the operating theatre: To safely remove the foreign body under controlled conditions, minimizing risk of further damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of ocular injuries involving foreign bodies, immediate removal is not advised due to the potential for further damage. Initial steps should focus on assessment, stabilization, and prevention of infection, followed by careful planning and execution of the foreign body removal under appropriate surgical conditions.

choices.text: Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain

questions.text: A young boy from high altitude came with fever and weakness and had the following reports Hemoglobin 17 gm%, TLC is 21,000 with neutrophils 25, lymphocytes 30, eosinophils 5, myelocytes and metamyelocytes 40 in peripheral smear. Next step in the investigation should be: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythropoietin levels

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Erythropoietin levels should be determined to differentiate primary from secondary forms.

 

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is characterized by increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis), but it is the increase in red cells (polycythemia), that is responsible for most of the clinical symptoms. PCV must be differentiated from relative polycythemia resulting from hemoconcentration and other causes of absolute polycythemia. PCV is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.

 

In PCV the progenitor cells have markedly decreased requirements for erythropoietin and other hematopoietic growth factors due to constitutive JAK2 signaling. Accordingly, serum erythropoietin levels in PCV are very low, whereas secondary forms of absolute polycythemia have high erythropoietin levels.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Philadelphia chromosome: This test is relevant in diagnosing chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), not polycythemia. While the presence of immature myeloid cells (myelocytes and metamyelocytes) could suggest a myeloproliferative disorder, the patient's clinical presentation and high hemoglobin level are more consistent with polycythemia, making erythropoietin testing a more appropriate next step.

 

Option B. JAK mutation: Testing for the JAK2 mutation is crucial in confirming a diagnosis of PCV. However, before proceeding to this test, it is important to measure erythropoietin levels to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. If erythropoietin levels are low, JAK2 mutation analysis would then be the next step.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow biopsy with reticulin stain: This investigation is used to evaluate bone marrow fibrosis, which can occur in myeloproliferative disorders like PCV. However, it is not the first-line investigation in this scenario. The erythropoietin level is a less invasive test that provides critical information to guide further diagnostic steps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin levels should be measured to differentiate between primary and secondary polycythemia. In cases of polycythemia vera, erythropoietin levels are typically low due to constitutive JAK2 signaling, while secondary polycythemia is associated with high erythropoietin levels.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, Pg 1161, 1242

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suggillation

 

The image shows post mortem staining on the back, also called suggillation. Post-mortem staining (PMS) is the settling of the blood in the dependent portions of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tattooing: Tattoos appear as distinct, well-defined patterns or designs, often in various colors. Tattoos can be located anywhere on the body and are not necessarily confined to dependent areas. They are typically intentional markings made by injecting ink into the skin.

 

Option C. Putrefaction: The body becomes greenish in colour in putrefaction. Later it becomes blackish.

 

Option D. Decomposition: Same explanation as that of putrefaction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Mortem Staining (PMS)

 

  •  It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • Other names of PMS are:
    • Hypostasis
    • livor mortis
    • Vibices
    • Suggillation
    • Postmortem Lividity
    • Cadaveric lividity
    • Darkening of death
  •  It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, but the right heart valves may also be involved in some cases.

 

Vegetations can be single or multiple, with one or more valves involved. Embolization is common and, due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli, can result in septic infarctions or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgment.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

 

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis shows small, friable vegetations.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding corporobasal index of the sacrum? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Breadth of first sacral vertebra X 100 / breadth of base of sacrum

 

  • Corporobasal index helps in determining the sex of the individual from the pelvis.
  • Corporobasal index = Breadth of first sacral vertebra x 100 / breadth of the base of the sacrum.
  • In males, it is >42 and in females, it is <42.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corporobasal index is calculated using the breadth of the first sacral vertebra and the breadth of the base of the sacrum, which helps in determining the sex of the individual.

 

Other Indices for Anthropometric Measurements:

questions.text: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Collar stud appearance  

 

The provided image depicts the right fundus of a patient, which indicates the presence of choroidal melanoma.

 

  • Angiography of the lesion: shows a distinct "double circulation" pattern, which represents the internal circulation within the tumor and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina.
  • On B-scan: pathognomonic feature called the "collar stud appearance" is visible. This appearance refers to a raised, dome-shaped tumor with a collar-like thickening at the base, caused by the accumulation of melanin and the infiltration of inflammatory cells at the tumor base.

 

 

Choroidal melanoma is a type of cancer that originates in the choroid, which is the vascular layer of the eye located between the retina and the sclera. It is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults and can lead to visual impairment and even metastasis to other organs. Therefore, it is crucial to diagnose and manage it promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoke-stack appearance: Typically associated with central serous retinopathy, showing a smoke-like leakage of fluid under the retina.

 

Option B. Inkblot appearance: Another pattern seen in central serous retinopathy where fluid leaks in a blot-like fashion.

 

Option D. Double circulation: While this feature can be seen in angiography of choroidal melanoma, it does not describe the ultrasonography appearance, which is specifically asked in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing choroidal melanoma via ultrasonography, the "collar stud appearance" is a key finding. Recognizing this feature, along with the clinical presentation of painless visual loss and metamorphopsia, supports a timely and accurate diagnosis of this potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: What is the normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2:3

 

Explanation: 


The normal arteriovenous (AV) ratio at the optic disc is 2:3. This ratio represents the normal relationship between arteriole and venule caliber at the optic disc. The artery appears lighter in color and has a thicker wall, while the vein appears darker and has a thinner wall. This ratio is important in assessing various ocular conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. 2:5: This is incorrect as it suggests arterioles are too narrow compared to venules. This ratio would indicate pathological narrowing of arterioles.

 

Option C. 1:5: This is incorrect and would represent a severely abnormal ratio suggesting significant arteriolar narrowing, which might be seen in advanced hypertensive retinopathy.

 

Option D. 1:3: While this ratio is seen in hypertensive retinopathy, it is not the normal AV ratio. In hypertensive retinopathy, there is narrowing of arterioles leading to a reduction in the AV ratio from 2:3 to 1:3.

 

Educational Objective: 


The normal arteriovenous ratio at the optic disc is 2:3, which serves as a baseline for evaluating vascular changes in various retinal conditions, particularly hypertensive retinopathy.

choices.text: Pulmonary infarction
Diffuse alveolar damage
Endothelial injury

questions.text: The most common lung finding in COVID 19 infection is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Diffuse alveolar damage may be seen in patients suffering from COVID-19.

 

COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include:

 

  1. Incipient pulmonary damage in early-stage disease with intraalveolar edema, endothelial necrosis, microthrombosis, and endothelialitis.
  2. Pneumocyte type 2 hyperplasia in exudative phase
  3. Multiple intraalveolar giant cells in exudative phase
  4. Hyaline membranes and solid fibrin deposits in exudative phase
  5. Thrombosis in small- to medium-sized vessels in early-stage lung disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary infarction: While pulmonary infarctions may occur due to thromboembolism, they are not the primary lung finding in COVID-19.

 

Option C. Endothelial injury: Endothelial injury does occur in COVID-19 and contributes to microvascular damage and thrombosis, but it is part of the broader picture of diffuse alveolar damage.

 

Option D. Fibrin clots: Fibrin clots are seen in COVID-19 as part of the coagulopathy associated with the disease, but they are secondary findings within the context of DAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is the most common and significant lung finding in severe COVID-19 infection, leading to the clinical syndrome of ARDS.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male addicted to recreational drugs, smoking and alcohol came to the OPD with complaints of excessive beating of heart and palpitations. On examination, there was episodic tachycardia and occasional extrasystole. Ophthalmic examination showed visual field defects. Which of the drugs is the likely cause?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cocaine

 

This is a sympathomimetic features (tachycardia, palpitation, arrhythmia like extrasystole) which are typical features of cocaine. Visual field defects can also occur with cocaine (due to vasoconstriction, and ischemia) though it is not common.

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and CVS:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious CVS Effects: Arrhythmias, Extrasystole, Myocardial Infarction
  • Seizures, Confusion 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicotine:

 

  • While nicotine can cause tachycardia and palpitations, but they are more pronounced and more common feature of cocaine.
  • Extrasystole are not a typical effect of nicotine use.
  • Nicotine does not cause visual Field Defects

 

Option C. Cannabis:

 

  • Cannabis usually causes mild symptoms, and mainly in CNS (Euphoria, altered perception, impaired cognitive function)
  • Tachycardia caused by cannabis is mild, not arrhythmias or palpitation
  • It does not cause visual field defects

 

Option D. Atropine:

 

  • Atropine is not typically a recreational drug.
  • Atropine causes moderate and controlled tachycardia, but not “episodic” tachycardia or extrasystole. Palpitations are more likely with cocaine as it is sympathomimetic.
  • Atropine can cause temporary mydriasis, but not visual field defects

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug that causes significant stimulant effects on the CNS and CVS, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia, palpitations, arrhythmias, and, occasionally, visual field defects due to vasoconstriction and ischemia.

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

 

  • The superior oblique muscle is responsible for three actions: intorsion, depression, and abduction.
  • Each eye has six extraocular muscles: four recti muscles and two oblique muscles.
  • The recti muscles are the superior, inferior, medial, and lateral rectus.
  • The superior oblique muscle originates from the apex of the orbit, turns around the trochlea, and inserts into the sclera behind the equator.
  • The tendon's oblique direction gives it a rotator effect, resulting in intorsion, as well as depression and abduction.
  • These muscles control both unilateral and binocular movements of the eye.
  • Unilateral eye movements are called Ductions.
  • Bilateral eye movements are called Versions.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine
Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the picture given below? (AIIMS May 2018,)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

The image shows aconite, a highly toxic plant. All parts of the aconite plant are poisonous, not just the roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Causes AV block: Correct statement. Aconite poisoning causes AV block due to its effects on the heart.

 

Option C. Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine: Correct statement. Atropine is used to counteract the bradycardia and AV block caused by aconite poisoning.

 

Option D. Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant: Correct statement. "Mitha zeher" is a common name for aconite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite:

 

  • All parts of the plant are poisonous.
  • Aconite is also called as - monkhood, mitha zeher, bish, and bikh.
  • Method of poisoning - It is a cardiac poison and causes AV block, bradycardia.
  • Treatment of choice - Atropine

questions.text:
All of the following statements are false about IL-12 except? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Increases production of interferon- γ
  2. Inhibits T cells
  3. Inhibits B cells
  4. Produced by macrophages
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is a cytokine produced primarily by antigen-presenting cells such as macrophages and dendritic cells. It plays a critical role in the immune response by promoting the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells, which are essential for cell-mediated immunity.

 

1. Increases production of interferon-γ (IFN-γ): IL-12 stimulates T cells and natural killer (NK) cells to produce IFN-γ, a cytokine crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

4. Produced by macrophages: IL-12 is indeed produced by macrophages, along with other antigen-presenting cells, in response to pathogens.

 

Other options:

 

2. Inhibits T cells: This is incorrect. IL-12 actually activates T cells, particularly promoting the differentiation into Th1 cells, rather than inhibiting them.

 

3. Inhibits B cells: This is also incorrect. IL-12 does not inhibit B cells; instead, it indirectly influences B cell function by promoting a Th1 response, which supports cellular immunity over humoral (B cell) immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon- γ (IFN- γ).

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

 

  • Diagnosis based on the given image: Pseudoexfoliation syndrome (PES)
  • PES is an age-related degenerative disorder, commonly seen in women.
  • Characterized by deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on:
    • Pupillary border
    • Anterior lens surface
    • Posterior surface of iris
    • Zonules
    • Ciliary processes
  • Trabecular blockage by exfoliative material can lead to:
    • Secondary open-angle glaucoma
    • Rarely, angle-closure glaucoma
  • Other ocular symptoms may include:
    • Iris sphincter atrophy
    • Anisocoria
    • Heterochromia
  • Systemic manifestations due to abnormal fibrillary deposition may also be seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.

  • Common intraocular foreign bodies:
    • Glass particles or metal chips.
  • Sites of lodgement: 
    • The anterior chamber
    • Lens
    • Posterior chamber
    • Vitreous humour
  • Consequences of lodgement: 
    • Cataract formation
    • Vitreous liquefaction
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Tears
    • Organic foreign bodies can cause infection.
    • Iron foreign bodies can cause siderosis.
    • Copper ones can result in chalcosis.
  • An entry wound can be identified with topical fluorescein.
  • MRI is contraindicated in metallic intraocular foreign bodies.

 

Option C.

 

Ocular trauma can be of 2 types:

  1. Closed-globe injury: can vary from simple corneal abrasions to widespread intraocular damage. A corneal abrasion highlighted with fluorescein staining is shown below.
  2. Open-globe injury: includes globe rupture or laceration.

 

 

Option D. Vossius ring is used to describe a ring-shaped pigment dispersal observed on the anterior surface of the lens due to the deposition of brown amorphous pigment granules. It is close to the constricted pupil in diameter. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, creating an impression of the iris on the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is characterized by the deposition of amorphous grey dandruff-like material on various parts of the eye, leading to potential complications like secondary open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor.
  • It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
  • The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:
    1. Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
    2. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
    3. Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)
    4. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

 

Note: Most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland: Adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can occur in various glands in the body, including the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by slow growth and the tendency to invade nearby structures.

 

Option C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is another type of malignant tumor that can affect the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by a combination of mucin-secreting and squamous (epidermoid) cells.

 

Option D. Malignant mixed tumor: Malignant mixed tumor, also known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma, occurs when a previously benign pleomorphic adenoma transforms into a malignant tumor. It is less common than pleomorphic adenoma but represents a more aggressive form of lacrimal gland tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is usually benign and arises from the glandular tissue. It can sometimes have a mixture of cell types, hence the name "pleomorphic."

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

 

The given clinical history with Russel bodies on histology points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies (INTRACYTOPLASMIC) are distended endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors (plasmacytomas) involving the axial skeleton.

 

Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent Golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus. Relatively normal appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.

 

Other cytologic variants stem from the dysregulated synthesis and secretion of Ig, which often leads to intracellular accumulation of intact or partially degraded protein.

 

Such variants include –

 

  • Flame cells with fiery red cytoplasm

 

 

  • Mott cells with multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets and cells containing a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of lymphoid cells, and while they can involve plasma cells, the presence of Russell bodies and the clinical history provided is more consistent with multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis: Leishmaniasis is a parasitic infection caused by protozoa of the genus Leishmania. It typically does not present with Russell bodies or the plasma cell abnormalities seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Urate nephropathy: Urate nephropathy involves the deposition of uric acid crystals in the kidneys, leading to kidney damage. This condition does not present with the histological features or clinical history described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Russell bodies in plasma cells, along with a clinical history of intractable diarrhea (suggestive of increased risk of infections due to nonfunctional antibodies), strongly suggests a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, a malignancy characterized by the abnormal proliferation of plasma cells.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, Page No. 1126

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

 

  • The clinical scenario described is due to right superior rectus palsy.
  • The three-step test, also called the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, can help diagnose which muscle is paralyzed in acquired hypertropia. It involves using the cover-uncover test and Maddox rod to measure deviation in different head positions.
  • The three-step test can also diagnose inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy, but it's not reliable for multiple paretic muscles or restrictive strabismus.
  • In patients with inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist, the three-step test can distinguish between true or simulated superior rectus palsy.

 

Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:

 

Step 1. Which eye is hypotropic?

 

The eye hypotropic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.

 

  • Right superior rectus
  • Right inferior oblique
  • Left inferior rectus
  • Left superior oblique

 

Step 2. Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?

 

The hypotropia increases in right gaze.

 

Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:

 

  • Left superior oblique
  • Right superior rectus

 

Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?

 

The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis typically leads to hypertropia and excyclotorsion, not hypotropia.

 

Option C. Right inferior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis would not result in the described pattern of hypotropia.

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique: Incorrect, since paralysis here does not explain the increase in hypotropia with right head tilt and right gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three-step test is a vital diagnostic tool in strabismus evaluations to identify which extraocular muscle is paretic based on the changes in eye position with head tilt and gaze direction. In this scenario, the findings align with a right superior rectus muscle palsy, consistent with its role in elevating the right eye especially during right gaze and head tilt to the right.

questions.text: Which surgical procedure should a 21-year-old boxer avoid to maintain optimal visual health? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RK

 

  • For a 21-year-old boxer who needs to maintain optimal visual health, understanding the differences between various refractive surgeries is crucial. 

 

Involves making radial cuts in the cornea to change its shape and correct refractive errors. It's not recommended for boxers because it weakens the structural integrity of the eye, making it more vulnerable to trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PRK (Photorefractive Keratectomy): This surgery involves removing the surface layer of the cornea to reshape it with a laser. It is safer than RK for athletes because it does not involve creating a flap, which could dislocate upon impact, though recovery can be slower.

 

Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis): LASIK surgery also reshapes the cornea but through creating a thin flap in the outer layer. While popular due to quick recovery times and immediate results, the flap might pose a risk in contact sports, as it could dislodge or move from direct impact.

 

Option D. SMILE (Small Incision Lenticule Extraction): The newest form of laser eye surgery, SMILE involves making a small, lenticule-shaped cut inside the cornea to reshape it without creating a flap. It offers a potentially safer option for athletes as it maintains more of the cornea's structural integrity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a boxer, avoiding procedures that compromise the cornea's physical integrity is crucial due to the high risk of impacts to the face. Among these options, RK and potentially LASIK present higher risks. SMILE or PRK might be safer alternatives, providing effective vision correction with a reduced risk of severe complications from physical trauma.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female was brought dead to the casualty. On examination there was frothing from her nose and mouth. What is the likely cause of death? (INICET NOVEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drowning

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to drowning.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway

  • Water in the stomach and small intestine

  • Water in middle ear

  • Cerebral edema

  • Bloated and cyanosed face

  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.

  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs

  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils

  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours

  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.

  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.

  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.

  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanging: Typically presents with a ligature mark around the neck, not frothing.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Often shows signs of external trauma to the neck, such as bruising or fractures, but not frothing.

 

Option D. Traumatic asphyxia: This results from severe chest compression, leading to petechiae and cyanosis but not usually frothing from the nose and mouth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frothing from the nose and mouth, along with other specific postmortem findings, strongly suggests drowning as the cause of death.

questions.text: A middle aged male presented with features of neck swelling, exophthalmos, sweating, tachycardia and tremors. Which of the following is the likely associated finding in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti thyroid receptor antibody

 

This patient presents with classic signs of hyperthyroidism, including:

 

  • Neck swelling → Goiter
  • Exophthalmos → Bulging eyes
  • Sweating, tachycardia, tremors → Signs of increased sympathetic activity

 

The given history and the picture of the patient suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism the commonest cause of which is Graves’s disease.

 

The most common antibody subtype, known as thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI), is observed in approximately 90% of patients. TSI binds to the TSH receptor and mimics its actions, stimulating adenyl cyclase and increasing the release of thyroid hormones.

 

  • Anti thyroid stimulating antibody cannot be the answer as such an antibody
  • Since TSI stimulates the gland for the formation of thyroid hormones. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-TPO antibody: Associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option B. Anti-thyroglobulin antibody: Also associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Option C. Anti-thyroid stimulating antibody: Incorrect terminology for TSI, which is already covered under anti-thyroid receptor antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease is associated with anti-thyroid receptor antibodies (TSI), which stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excess thyroid hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism. The presence of neck swelling, exophthalmos, and other hyperthyroid symptoms strongly suggests this diagnosis.

 

Graves Disease – Key Features:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1081

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) After cataract

 

(SYNONYMS: POSTERIOR CAPSULAR OPACIFICATION/SECOND CATARACT)

 

  • Elschnig's pearls are a type of after cataract, a delayed complication of cataract surgery.
  • They are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles, along the posterior capsule of the lens.

 

Types of after cataract:

 

  • ﻿﻿Thin membranous after-cataract (thickened posterior capsule)
  • ﻿﻿Dense membranous after-cataract
  • ﻿﻿Soemmering ring: peripheral thick ring of opacity between 2 capsules.
  • ﻿Elschnig's pearls

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Irvine-Gass syndrome:

 

  • Postoperative cystoid macular edema classically described as vitreous touch syndrome.
  • Can occur upto 6 months post cataract surgery.
  • Resolves on its own.
  • Non resolving Irvine Gass syndrome is treated with topical NSAID eye drops, intra and periocular steroid injection and intravitreal Anti-VEGF injection.

 

Option C. Endophthalmitis:

 

  • Caused by an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becoming trapped within the capsular bag
  • Characterized by pain and redness
  • Delayed complication
  • Treatment is removal of entire IOL-Bag complex along with vitrectomy and secondary IOL implantation – either sclera fixation / iris claw IOL / Anterior chamber IOL.

 

Option D. Uveitis-glaucoma-hyphema syndrome:

 

  • Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously
  • Seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation
  • Also seen when foldable hydrophilic IOL is implanted in ciliary sulcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior capsular opacification or after cataract is a common post-surgical complication following cataract surgery, characterized by the proliferation of lens epithelial cells leading to opacification of the posterior capsule. This can diminish vision and may require further treatment, typically a simple laser procedure called a YAG capsulotomy to restore clarity to the visual axis.

questions.text: A child presents with recurrent chest infections and abdominal pain. There is a history of 1 blood transfusion in the past. On examination, he had icterus and mild splenomegaly. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2, HbF, and S spike. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sickle cell disease

 

The given scenario with increased HbA2, HbF, and S spikes on electrophoresis suggests sickle cell disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The fundamental molecular lesion: The basic genetic defect in HbS is a single point mutation in one amino acid out of 146 in the hemoglobin molecule—there is a substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6-residue position of the beta -globin, producing HbS.  This causes sickle-shaped red blood cells to be produced due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

 

Infection, dehydration, and acidosis are all risk factors for sickling.

 

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated. The features are:

 

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice.
  • Vaso-occlusive phenomenon due to obstruction to capillary blood flow by sickled red cells upon deoxygenation or dehydration:
    • Microinfarcts affecting particularly the abdomen, chest, back and joints and are the cause of recurrent painful crises in SS.
    • Microinfarcts involving most commonly the spleen (splenic sequestration, auto splenectomy), bone marrow (pains), bones (aseptic necrosis, osteomyelitis), lungs.
    • (Pulmonary infections), kidneys (renal cortical necrosis), CNS (stroke), retina (damage) and skin (ulcers), and result in anatomic and functional damage to these organs.
  • Aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Hemophilus influenza septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta thalassemia: Typically presents with severe anemia and requires frequent blood transfusions. Electrophoresis shows increased HbA2 and HbF but does not show a significant S spike.

 

Option B. HbC disease: Characterized by the presence of hemoglobin C, which does not cause the severe symptoms seen in sickle cell disease. Electrophoresis would show HbC rather than HbS.

 

Option D. Acute coronary disease: Not relevant to the presentation described, as it does not explain the recurrent infections, abdominal pain, icterus, and splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sickle cell disease is characterized by the presence of HbS, leading to recurrent infections, abdominal pain, hemolytic anemia, and splenomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2, HbF, and an S spike. The genetic mutation involves the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the 6th position of the β-globin chain.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain, photophobia and redness of the right eye since 2 days. He gave a history of injury by a leaf, to the same eye, 5 days back. What is the likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fungal corneal ulcer

 

The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer.

 

Fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter or injury by animal tail.

 

A very characteristic feature of fungal corneal ulcer is that the Signs are much more than Symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior uveitis: This involves inflammation of the middle layer of the eye, which can cause pain and redness but does not involve the specific corneal changes seen in fungal ulcers.

 

Option B. Conjunctivitis: An inflammation or infection of the outer membrane of the eyeball and the inner eyelid, typically causing redness and discharge, not the specific features of a corneal ulcer.

 

Option D. Corneal laceration: While also a result of trauma, lacerations would generally present immediately post-injury with sharp, distinct cuts, rather than developing signs of infection such as those described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fungal corneal ulcer should be considered when a patient presents with eye symptoms following trauma involving vegetative or organic material. Key diagnostic features include a greyish-white ulcer with feathery margins, potentially accompanied by a hypopyon, and absence of corneal vascularization.

questions.text: A girl runs away from home with her boyfriend and they get married. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the boy. Identify the approximate age of the girl from the Xray picture of her pelvis? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 21 years

 

The ischial tuberosity in the X ray is fused, hence the age is > 21 years

 

Some students can get confused and are not able to distinguish whether ischial tuberosity has fused or not yet appeared. It is not possible that ischial tuberosity has not yet appeared because the upper end of femur (head, greater trochanter, lesser trochanter) has fused with shaft which occurs between 17- 19 years, whereas ischial tuberosity appears earlier at 16 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Femur

 

Upper end of Femur is composed of three centres:

 

  • Head – 1 yr (A)             
  • Greater Trochanter- 4 yr (A)
  • Lesser trochanter – 14 yr (A)          

 

These three centres fuse with shaft at 17- 19 yrs of age

 

Pelvis
